definition: official authority used for private interests (idiom); to attain private ends by abusing public position
variant of 假[jia3]/to borrow
fake/false/artificial/to borrow/if/suppose
vacation
see 假掰[gei1 bai1]

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
to cross a river/to aid or relieve/to be of help
only used in 濟濟|济济[ji3 ji3]
used in place names associated with the Ji River 濟水|济水[Ji3 Shui3]/surname Ji
personal/private/selfish

sentences.english: He said he would not job his son into the position .
sentences.chinese: 他说，他不会假公济私为他儿子安排那个职位。

sentences.english: To overdo anything public may lead to jobbery while appropriate selfishness may promote the growth.
sentences.chinese: “公”字过头可能假公济私，私心适度也会促进发展。

sentences.english: He said he wouldn't job his son into the position.
sentences.chinese: 他说，他不会假公济私为他儿子安排那个职位。

sentences.english: Their jobs were all exposed by the press.
sentences.chinese: 他们假公济私的勾当全被报纸揭了出来。

definition: to use one's position for personal gain (idiom)
to use public office to avenge private wrongs
to stuff one's pockets/to take bribes
to damage the public interest for personal profit (idiom); personal profit at public expense/venal and selfish behavior
to bend the law in order to favor one's relatives or associates (idiom)
to harbor evil intentions (idiom)
to gain from corrupt dealing/to engage in graft/to feather one's nest
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
corruption and abuse of the law (idiom); to take bribes and bend the law
see 徇私舞弊[xun4 si1 wu3 bi4]
harboring unfathomable motives (idiom)
to make a profit/to gain/to get an advantage
abuse of power
to misappropriate (public funds etc)/to embezzle
to work against the interests of sb one derives support from/to double-cross one's employer/to bite the hand that feeds you
to retaliate
